entry.content:
Sapphire Complex Daily Update 09.07.2017

Incident: Sapphire Complex Wildfire
Released: 32 min. ago

Related Information

  • Sapphire Complex Daily Update 09.07.2017 (pdf 41 kb)

Three fires comprise the Sapphire Complex: Little Hogback, Goat Creek, and Sliderock fires. The fires are burning in steep, rocky terrain between the Rock Creek and Upper Willow Creek drainages. Mike Dueitt’s Southeastern Type I Incident Management Team (IMT) will assume command of both the Sapphire Complex and the Meyers Fire beginning at 6:00pm tonight. Beginning this evening, the contact phone number for both fires will be 406-859-9107, and the Incident Command Post will be moving to the Meyers Fire camp off of Skalkaho Road.

Little Hogback Fire: 34,310 acres, 30% contained.

Fire continued to spread slowly on the southwestern flank and along the northern perimeter. Crews finished constructing hand line, tying in to existing lines along Windlass Gulch, hoping to prevent the fire from spreading further. Firefighters were able to burnout into Windless Gulch and hand lines continue to hold there. Mop up operations continue on the east side of the fire, and crews are performing suppression repair where practical. Crews continue to provide structure protection along Rock Creek Road and helicopters aided firefighters by cooling hot spots in the remote terrain. Structure protection measures (including extensive hoselays) are still in place along Rock Creek Road. Preventing fire growth toward homes and ranches continues to dictate operational priorities, and protection of life is always the primary objective.

Goat Creek Fire: 8,305 acres, 95% contained.

Rehabilitation of firelines and suppression activities continues in earnest.

Sliderock Fire: 901 acres, 95% contained.

Crews continue to mop up hotspots and patrol the Sliderock Fire.

Resources Threatened: Private property and structures in the Rock Creek, Upper Willow Creek, and Marshall Creek drainages remain threatened. Other resources threatened include fisheries in Rock Creek, grazing lands along the southern boundary of the Little Hogback Fire, Bonneville Power Administration powerline, and a communication site.

Evacuations: A Level Red-Evacuation Order for approximately thirty-five residences along Rock Creek Road remains in effect, beginning from and including Wild Rose Loop south to Stony Creek. All other Level Yellow-Pre-evacuation notices are still in effect. For information on evacuation planning refer to the Ready-Set-Go materials available at http://www.wildlandfirersg.org/Portals/18/Resources/States/MT/RSG_Montana_ActionGuide_web.pdf

Closures: The Rock Creek Road from I-90 south to Bitterroot Campground (MP 23.5) is OPEN. Due to fire traffic congestion and fire safety concerns, Rock Creek Road will stay CLOSED from Bitterroot Campground, south to Cornish Gulch (FSR5027), and public traffic is NOT allowed. Upper Willow Creek Road is currently closed to the public. The Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest reduced closure restrictions in the Black Pine ridge area, but maintains all area closures in Upper Willow Creek, North Fork Lower Willow Creek, and Harvey Creek areas. The Bureau of Land Management has an area closure in Upper Willow Creek, Ram Mountain, and nearby areas. The Lolo and Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forests, the Bureau of Land Management, and the Montana Department of Natural Resources (DNRC) closure orders and maps are posted under the closures tab on Inciweb. Please adhere to all closures and allow our firefighters to perform their jobs safely.

Weather:

Smoky conditions moderated temperatures on Wednesday, but they still climbed into the mid-80’s, while humidity dropped to near 10%. Thursday will continue to be warm and dry with light, terrain dominated winds.

Fire Restrictions: Stage 1 Fire Restrictions are in place on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest (Forest Service land east of Sandstone Ridge), with the additional modification to prohibit all campfires. Stage 2 Fire Restrictions are in place on BLM, private and state lands in Granite County, and the Lolo National Forest (Forest Service land west of Sandstone Ridge). For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us.

entry.content:
Meyers Fire Update for September 7, 2017

Incident: Meyers Fire Wildfire
Released: 31 min. ago

Related Information

  • Meyers Fire Update September 7, 2017 (pdf 94 kb)

Current Size: 57,933 acres
Resources Assigned: 376

Status: The fire is burning in mixed conifer stands, primarily lodgepole pine, Douglas-fir, and subalpine fir, with numerous standing dead trees. There are residences still at risk in the Moose Lake, Frog Pond, Billy Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza Lands areas.

Yesterday’s Activities: Thick smoke laid across the fire limiting fire growth much of the day. Winds were favorable for burnout operations in Moose Lake and Zeke’s Meadows later in the day. Both burnout operations were successful in reducing fuels in these areas to limit future fire spread. Reconnaissance flights over the fire confirmed fire is active on the east side of the Continental Divide in Howell Creek. Firefighters started assessing structures and other values at risk in advance of the fire on the east side of the Divide. Crews were shared with the Sapphire Complex to assist with their burning operations. Mike Dueitt’s Southern Area Type 1 Team met with the Meyers Fire and Sapphire Complex teams, local land management agencies, and cooperators to begin transition of incident management.

Current Resources: Five 20-person crews, twenty-one engines, four pieces of heavy equipment (skidgines, dozers, masticators), ten water tenders, and three helicopters. Total personnel: 376.

Today’s Activities: The high pressure weather system that moved into the area will hold the smoke over the fire area. This will again limit fire activity. Most of the fire growth will occur due to slope and terrain, not wind. Structure protection is still the priority on the fire. Crews will patrol and mop up the previous day’s burnout operations to ensure no heat remains. Machine and hand line is still under construction on the East Fork of the Bitterroot around the 2 subdivisions. Firefighters will hold and improve lines in Frog Pond and conduct burnout operations where feasible. The Type 1 team will be shadowing both the Sapphire Complex and Meyers Fire personnel before taking command of the fires at 6:00 p.m.

Evacuations: The Frog Pond and Moose Lake areas are under an evacuation order. Additionally, an evacuation warning is in effect on East Fork Rd from FS Rd 5778 to Little East Fork Rd (FS RD 724) on the Bitterroot National Forest. Those under an evacuation warning should be prepared to leave at a moment’s notice.

Restrictions/Closures: Closure orders are in place on both National Forests. Bitterroot National Forest emergency closure orders are in effect for upper areas of the East Fork Bitterroot River. The Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest has expanded the emergency closure order around the fire. A temporary flight restriction (TFR) is in effect surrounding the Meyers Fire area. Granite County is under Stage 2 fire restrictions for private lands in the county. Amended Stage 1 fire restrictions are in effect today which prohibits ALL campfires in southwestern Montana on public lands, including in fire rings and developed recreation areas. For fire restriction details, visit firerestrictions.us/mt.

For further information, follow the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest Facebook and Bitterroot National Forest Facebook pages.

Meyers Fire Update September 6th, 2017

Incident: Meyers Fire Wildfire
Released: 20 min. ago

Related Information

  • Printable Meyers Fire Update September 6th, 2017 (pdf 95 kb)

Current Size: 56,333 acres Resources Assigned: 345

Status: The fire is burning in mixed conifer stands, primarily lodgepole pine, Douglas fir, and subalpine fir, with numerous standing dead trees. There are residences still at risk in the Moose Lake, Frog Pond, Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza Lands areas.

Yesterday’s Activities: The significant change in fire weather conditions the past two days gave firefighters a chance to reassess and adress the fire growth that occurred over the holiday weekend. The crews working at Moose Lake had the time and space to safely reset sprinkler systems throughout the community and perform burnout operations west of the Mooselake Rd. Around the Springer Memorial Park, dozer and hand line construction will provide a fire control line while sprinkler systems and other structure protection measures are implemented around buildings within the park. South of Frog Pond western extension of the fire front was assessed for its potential to impact the area from a new direction. Crews continued to prepare cabins to resist the fire’s approach. On the north end of the fire, burning conditions were not conducive to black line or burnout operations. Instead, crews used direct attack in the bottom of Senate Creek to contain a small spot fire.

Current Resources: Four 20-person crews, twenty-one engines, four pieces of heavy equipment (skidgines, dozers, masticators), ten water tenders, and three helicopters. Total personnel: 345.

Today’s Activities: With a warming trend and west/northwest winds returning to the Meyers Fire area, increases in fire activity can be expected. Firefighters will utilize conditions to their advantage to complete burnout operations east of Zeke’s meadow, south and west of Moose Lake, and in advantageous places within the Frog Pond area. Point protection of houses will continue as these tactics are implemented and in anticipation of expected fire advance. Bull dozer and hand line construction around Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza is ongoing as structure assessments and preparations are made amidst the communities. With the fire’s advance southeast across the Continental Divide into the upper portions of Howell’s Creek, firefighters are making aerial and ground observations to determine a course of action for point protection of values at risk. Mike Dueitt’s Southern Area Type 1 Incident Management Team will be arriving in Montana and familiarizing themselves with the Meyers Fire and Sapphire Complex. Management and command of the fires will transition to the new team on Thursday September 7, 2017 at 6:00PM.

Evacuations: The Frog Pond and Moose Lake areas are under an evacuation order. Additionally, an evacuation warning is in effect on East Fork Rd from FS Rd 5778 to Little East Fork Rd (FS RD 724) on the Bitterroot National Forest. Those under an evacuation warning should be prepared to leave at a moment’s notice.

Restrictions/Closures: Closure orders are in place on both National Forests. Bitterroot National Forest emergency closure orders are in effect for upper areas of the East Fork Bitterroot River. Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest has an emergency closure order around the fire extending into the Anaconda Pintler Wilderness. A temporary flight restriction (TFR) is in effect surrounding the Meyers Fire area. Granite County is under Stage 2 fire restrictions for private lands in the county. Amended Stage 1 fire restrictions are in effect today which prohibits ALL campfires in southwestern Montana on public lands, including in fire rings and developed recreation areas. For fire restriction details, visit firerestrictions.us/mt.

For further information, follow the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest Facebook and Bitterroot National Forest Facebook pages.

Incident: The Meyers Fire was started by lightning on July 14, 2017. It merged with the Whetstone Fire (3,621 acre), also started by lightning, on July 13, 2017.

Location: 25 miles southwest of Philipsburg, Montana.

Agency Jurisdiction: USDA Forest Service, Beaverhead-Deerlodge and Bitterroot National Forests

Incident Management: Irv Leach’s Northern Rockies Type 2 Incident Management Team.

Current Size: 54,814 acres Resources Assigned: 344

Yesterday’s Activities: Overall fire activity moderated due to lower temperatures, smoky skies shading the fire, and a reduction in wind speed. Smoke limited helicopter use, but they were able to support water bucket drops southwest of Kaiser Lake up the Senate Creek drainage. Pumps and sprinklers are in working order around the residences. Frog Pond and Moose Lake structures have not been damaged by the fire growth around them. At the Springer Memorial and Bonanza Lands area, the hand line and machine line under constructions were prepped and brought in closer to the existing subdivisions. The containment dropped from five percent to zero based on the increases fire perimeter on Sunday.

Current Resources: Three 20-person crews, twenty engines, four pieces of heavy equipment (skidgines, dozers, masticators), ten water tenders, and three helicopters. Total personnel: 344.

Today’s Activities: Today will generally be warmer across the Meyers Fire area with light winds coming from the east. Fire behavior will be less affected by wind and driven more by terrain and should be similar to yesterday due to the smoke cover preventing the sun’s warmth heating the fuels. Structure protection measures are strong in resident areas of Frog Pond, Moose Lake, and East Fork Bitterroot. Some crews will be moving to the Bitterroot National Forest side of the fire to help work on the in-direct line around Spinger Memorial. Burning operations around Zeke’s Meadow and Moose Lake plan to bring fire closer to the lines built over the last few weeks.

Evacuations: The Frog Pond and Moose Lake areas are under an evacuation order. Additionally, an evacuation warning is in effect on East Fork Rd from FS Rd 5778 to Little East Fork Rd (FS RD 724) on the Bitterroot National Forest. Those under an evacuation warning should be prepared to leave at a moment’s notice.

Restrictions/Closures: Closure orders are in place on both National Forests. Bitterroot National Forest emergency closure orders are in effect for upper areas of the East Fork Bitterroot River. Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest has an emergency closure order around the fire extending into the Anaconda Pintler Wilderness. A temporary flight restriction (TFR) is in effect surrounding the Meyers Fire area. Granite County is under Stage 2 fire restrictions for private lands in the county. Amended Stage 1 fire restrictions are in effect today which prohibits ALL campfires in southwestern Montana on public lands, including in fire rings and developed recreation areas. For fire restriction details, visit firerestrictions.us/mt.

For further information, follow the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest Facebook and Bitterroot National Forest Facebook pages.

Email: meyerswhetstone@gmail.com

Incident: The Meyers Fire was started by lightning on July 14, 2017. It merged with the Whetstone Fire (3,621 acre), also started by lightning, on July 13, 2017.

Location: 25 miles southwest of Philipsburg, Montana.

Agency Jurisdiction: USDA Forest Service, Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest

Cooperating Agencies: Georgetown Lake Volunteer Fire Department, Granite County Commissioners, Granite County Sheriff’s Office, Ravalli County Sheriff’s Office, Granite County Office of Emergency Management, Ravalli County Office of Emergency Management, Montana DNRC, and Montana National Guard.

Incident Management: Irv Leach’s Northern Rockies Type 2 Incident Management Team.

Current Size: 53,737 acres Resources Assigned: 334

Status: The fire is burning in mixed conifer stands, primarily lodgepole pine, Douglas fir, and subalpine fir, with numerous standing dead trees. There are residences still at risk in the Moose Lake, Frog Pond, Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza areas.

Yesterday’s Activities: Fire activity was high on the south and east sides of the fire with significant growth in Fishtrap Creek and Carpp Creek drainages. The fire has grown to the east of the Continental Divide on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge and Bitterroot National Forests. The fire grew over 15,000 acres. Indirect, contingency lines, and perimeter structure protection continued in the Frog Pond, Moose Lake, Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza Lands communities. Structure protection and life safety continue to be priorities. Engines and National Guard fire equipment are in place in the Moose Lake subdivision. The Granite County Sheriff ordered a mandatory evacuation for Moose Lake last night. Additional burning and chipping of fuels was completed around Frog Pond residential area. Crews worked to limit fire spread north of Zekes Meadow using helicopter water drops, but the old cabin in the meadow burned down.

Current Resources: Three 20-person crews, nineteen engines, four pieces of heavy equipment (skidgines, dozers, masticators), ten water tenders, and three helicopters. Total personnel: 334.

Today’s Activities: Temperatures will be lower today, in the mid 70’s and humidity will be slightly higher. The wind will switch and be out of the northeast. Fire activity is expected to moderate today. Across the fire, point protection for structures remains the priority. Sprinklers are in place and are continually tested. Construction will continue on hand and machine line around Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza Land residences. The line east from Zekes Meadow will be assessed to determine if it can be used for future burn out operations. Operations in Frog Pond area will bring the fire along the edges of meadows to further reduce fuels and secure the line. Engines and National Guard fire equipment is in place around Moose Lake.

Evacuations: The Frog Pond and Moose Lake areas are under an evacuation order. Additionally, an evacuation warning is in effect on East Fork Rd from FS Rd 5778 to Little East Fork Rd (FS RD 724) on the Bitterroot National Forest. Those under an evacuation warning should be prepared to leave at a moment’s notice.

Restrictions/Closures: Expanded closure orders were issued on both National Forests yesterday. Bitterroot National Forest emergency closure orders are in effect for upper areas of the East Fork Bitterroot River. Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest has an emergency closure order around the fire extending into the Anaconda Pintler Wilderness. A temporary flight restriction (TFR) is in effect surrounding the Meyers Fire area. Granite County is under Stage 2 fire restrictions for private lands in the county. Amended Stage 1 fire restrictions are in effect today which prohibits ALL campfires in southwestern Montana on public lands, including in fire rings and developed recreation areas.

For further information, follow the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest Facebook and Bitterroot National Forest Facebook pages.

Sapphire Complex Daily Update 09/04/17

Incident: Sapphire Complex Wildfire
Released: 1:00 hrs. ago

Related Information

Three fires comprise the Sapphire Complex: Little Hogback, Goat Creek, and Sliderock fires. Mike Almas’ Northern Rockies Type II Incident Management Team (IMT) is managing the incident. The fires are burning in steep, rocky terrain between the Rock Creek and Upper Willow Creek drainages.

Little Hogback Fire: 32,698 acres, 30% contained.

Sunday, the southwestern flank continued spreading up canyon into Windlass Gulch. Crews continued to provide point protection for structures along Rock Creek Road and helicopters aided firefighters by cooling hot spots in the remote terrain. Fire managers are looking at several options for contingency lines to help stop fire spread to the north and east of Rock Creek Road. Structure protection measures (including extensive hoselays) are still in place along Rock Creek Road. Preventing fire growth toward homes and ranches continues to dictate operational priorities, and protection of life is always the primary objective.

Goat Creek Fire: 8,305 acres, 95% contained.

Rehabilitation of firelines and fuel break construction is progressing rapidly, and crews continue to mop up interior hot spots.

Sliderock Fire: 901 acres, 95% contained.

Crews continue to mop up hotspots and patrol the Sliderock Fire, resulting in increased containment.

Resources Threatened: Private property and structures in the Rock Creek, Upper Willow Creek, and Marshall Creek drainages remain threatened. Other resources threatened include fisheries in Rock Creek, grazing lands along the southern boundary of the Little Hogback Fire, Bonneville Power Administration powerline, and a communication site.

Evacuations: Due to fire activity on the Little Hogback fire and predicted weather conditions, the Granite County Sheriff issued a Level Red-Evacuation Order for some residences along Rock Creek Road, effective Saturday, September 2, at 10:00 p.m. The Level Red- Evacuation Order was issued to residences along both sides of Upper Rock Creek Road and adjacent roads/neighborhoods, beginning from and including Wild Rose Loop south to Stony Creek. Approximately 35 residences are impacted by the Level Red- Evacuation order. All other Level Yellow-Pre-evacuation notices are still in effect.

Closures: The Rock Creek Road from I-90 south to Bitterroot Campground (MP 23.5) is OPEN. Due to fire traffic congestion and fire safety concerns, the Rock Creek Road will continue to be CLOSED from Bitterroot Campground, south to Cornish Gulch (FSR5027), and public traffic is NOT allowed. Upper Willow Creek Road is currently closed to the public. The Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest has reduced closure restrictions in the Black Pine ridge area, but maintains all area closures in the Upper Willow Creek, North Fork Lower Willow Creek, and Harvey Creek areas. The Bureau of Land Management has implemented an area closure in the Upper Willow Creek, Ram Mountain, and nearby areas. The Lolo and Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forests and the Bureau of Land Management have posted closure orders and maps under the closures tab on Inciweb.

Weather: Conditions continued to be hot and very dry on Sunday with gusty winds out of the west-northwest. A cold front moved through overnight, bringing with it cooler temperatures, slightly higher humidities and lighter winds out of the east-northeast, however a red flag warning will continue to be in effect through Monday evening.

Fire Restrictions: Stage 1 Fire Restrictions are in place on the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest (Forest Service land east of Sandstone Ridge), with the additional modification to prohibit all campfires. Stage 2 Fire Restrictions are in place on BLM, private and state lands in Granite County, and the Lolo National Forest (Forest Service land west of Sandstone Ridge). For information on fire restrictions, please visit firerestrictions.us.

entry.content:
Meyers Fire Update September 3, 2017

Incident: Meyers Fire Wildfire
Released: 5 min. ago

Current Size: 37,649 acres
Resources Assigned: 333


Red flag warning issued till 9 p.m. tonight. No campfires allowed.


Status: The fire is burning in mixed conifer stands, primarily lodgepole pine, Douglas fir, and subalpine fir, with numerous standing dead trees. There are residences still at risk in the Moose Lake, Frog Pond, Springer Memorial Park and Bonanza areas.

Yesterday’s Activities: Fire activity was highest around Zeke’s Meadow, Porter Ridge, and Reynolds Creek on the Bitterroot National Forest. Overall the fire grew over 7000 acres. Indirect, contingency lines, and perimeter structure protection were prepped in the East Fork of the Bitterroot area of the fire. The McCart lookout is nearly complete with foil wrapping. The indirect line near Zeke’s meadow is also nearly complete in preparation for possible burnout in the future. Conditions were favorable in the Frog Pond area for burnout operations in green areas of the fire and helicopters were able to drop water on areas to slow the growth in other areas. Structure protection is still a priority for Moose Lake. A packer bridge sustained some railing damage from fire, but remains serviceable. Sprinklers were set on the bridges to prevent any further damage. Helicopters made 156 water drops, but had to stop operations later in the day because of high winds.

Current Resources: Three 20-person crews, seventeen engines, four pieces of heavy equipment (dozers, masticators), ten water tenders, and three helicopters. Total personnel: 333.

Today’s Activities: Today is a critical fire weather day. A Red Flag warning has been issued and will remain in effect till 9 p.m. tonight. With temperatures 20 degrees above normal, extremely low humidity, sustained winds with gusts, significant fire growth is forecasted. Expect large smoke plumes. The most intense fire growth is projected in the East Fork of the Bitterroot moving east. Smoke from the fire activity in the East Fork Bitterroot will influence the progression of fire east of Moose Lake Road. Across the fire, point protection for structures will remain the priority. Crews will grid for spot fire on the east side of Moose Lake Road (FS Road 5106) to keep the fire west of the road north of Moose Lake. Hand and machine line construction is expected to start from the East Fork Road. The indirect line near Zeke’s Meadow will be improved today with a 20 person hot shot crew.

Evacuations: The Frog Pond area is under an evacuation order. Moose Lake residents are under an evacuation warning. Additionally, an evacuation warning is in effect on East Fork Rd from FS Rd 5778 to Little East Fork Rd (FS RD 724) on the Bitterroot National Forest. Those under an evacuation warning should be prepared to leave at a moment’s notice.

Restrictions/Closures: Bitterroot National Forest emergency closure orders are in effect for upper areas of the East Fork Bitterroot River. Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest emergency closure orders are in effect around the fire area. The closure of Forest Roads 893, 8684 and 8685 was rescinded at 6:00AM Friday, September 1, 2017. A temporary flight restriction (TFR) is in effect surrounding the Meyers Fire area. Granite County is under Stage 2 fire restrictions for private lands in the county. Amended Stage 1 fire restrictions have gone into effect today which prohibit ALL campfires in southwestern Montana, including in fire rings and developed recreation areas.

For further information, follow the Beaverhead-Deerlodge National Forest Facebook and Bitterroot National Forest Facebook pages.
